awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Center for Neural Science Summer Undergraduate Research Program (SURP)
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site Award to New York University Washington Square Campus, located in New York City, NY, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2020-2022. It is anticipated that a total of 30 students will be from schools with limited neuroscience research opportunities or from an under-represented group, including first generations to attend college. The program will include students from junior colleges or with marginal GPAs but with recommendation letters and personal statements revealing self-directed, inquisitive minds. Students will learn how neuroscience research is designed and conducted. They will practice writing their scientific research paper and research proposal through weekly written assignments. All students will be coached on oral presentation skills, leading them to present their research activities at scientific conferences. Students will witness the diversity of paths available for growing up in science through small weekly group luncheons with research mentors. Assessment of the program will be done through the online SALG URSSA tool. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths.

The scientific focus of the REU-Site is neural science. Students will be placed in one of the laboratories that are within Center for Neural Science of NYU Washington Square Campus. Almost all CNS faculty mentors have joint appointments with other departments, encompassing Psychology, Biology, Economics, Data Science, NYU Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, the Nathan Kline Institute for Psychiatric Research, and others These collaborative research activities will provide students with the glimpse of the highly synergistic nature and societal relevance of neuroscience research, demonstrating to them the Broad Impact of neuroscience research. All students will receive weekly in-person training in ethics/responsible conduct of research. Students initiate the online application process (currently by obtaining an NSF_REU ID by registering at  https://www.nsfreu.org). The ten NSF-REU participants, from an applicant pool of >300, will be selected jointly by the PI, co-PI, and research mentors. More information about the program is available by visiting http://as.nyu.edu/content/nyu-as/as/departments/cns/UndergraduateProgram/summer-research-program.html or by contacting the PI at surpinfo@cns.nyu.edu.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
History reveals the long-standing commitment of the  Center for Neural Science and NYU to broadening undergraduate research opportunities. The CNS-Summer Undergraduate  Research Program (SURP) was funded as a model program in1990 and was supported through 1998 by the Howard Hughes Medical Institute (HHMI). During thesubsequent two years, CNS-SURP continued on a reduced level, funded by a one-time grant from NYU’s Curriculum Development Challenge Fund, then supported annually using funds from the Dean of the College of Arts and Science, the Dean for Science, and faculty’s research grants. External support was resumed in 2000 and has continued uninterrupted to 2023 through the NSF-REU Site grant, which boosted the CNS-SURP greatly. Throughout these years, faculty, post-docs and graduate students have volunteered to contribute their time as mentors, seminar leaders, boot camp instructors and directors.

Neuroscience encompasses biological studies of the brain’s role in nature-nurture, learning and memory, perception, planning, action, emotion, individuality, and social interactions. It is a field that is easily relatable to personal experience and highly interdisciplinary, using tools developed that are biophysical, chemical, mechanical, cellular, molecular, and computational. This makes the field attractive to a broad spectrum of students and the research outcome broadly impactful to society.  The summer undergraduate research program has taken advantage of this natural attraction to the field of neuroscience and has broadened the population of students entering a career path in basic research by targeting undergraduates who are (i) from diverse backgrounds or with disabilities (ii) first generation to attend college (1st GEN); (iii) socio-economically disadvantaged; and/or (iv) attending smallcolleges that do not offer research opportunities in neuroscience (LimitedNS).

The success of the SURP_NSF_REU program is due to collaborative research activities that provide all SURP students with a glimpse into the highly synergistic and socially relevant nature of neuroscience research. This enables them to witness the broad impact of neuroscience research in action. During the last funded period (2020-2023), 17 laboratories, along with 4 additional universities (via Zoom during the COVID year of 2020), have hosted undergraduates in the CNS-SURP program. All participating institutions have expressed interest in continuing to mentor undergraduates.

Participation in CNS/SURP research has been highly impactful. Of the 51 CNS-SURP alumni from 2017-2021 (93% from diverse backgrounds and none from NYU), 36 (71%) entered STEM research after graduating from college. Additionally, 17 (33%) of these alumni became co-authors in academic journals, and 17 (33%) enrolled in PhD programs.

 

 

 

 

.

 


Last Modified: 05/22/2024
Modified by: Margarita Kaplow

During thesubsequent two years, CNS-SURP continued on a reduced level, funded by a one-time grant from NYUs Curriculum Development Challenge Fund, then supported annually using funds from the Dean of the College of Arts and Science, the Dean for Science, and facultys research grants. External support was resumed in 2000 and has continued uninterrupted to 2023 through the NSF-REU Site grant, which boosted the CNS-SURP greatly.
